Pro-Am information for 2024. We are hosting at Briggs Ranch in San Antonio Texas!!!!! 

We can confidently say this will be the best one we will put together. 

BackSwing will finish the year working over 2,500 events and supporting almost 300 women across the U.S. This Pro-Am will feed into the BackSwing Invitational which will be held the following day. Our goal is to get that purse to 100k that these ladies compete for. This will be a kickoff to their professional season on tour.

Some details for the event. ALL sponsorships (other than the “foursome”), include your own high end cottage with 4 bedrooms and 4 bathrooms. You have 4 players plus a pro this year for the pro-am. ALL drinks, ALL food and lodging is included in your sponsorship. 

BackSwing has the entire property at Briggs. You are able to arrive anytime on Feb 20th after 2pm and play/hit balls enjoy a cocktail or just hang out! We are going to have some fun games/music entertainment starting at 5pm on the range as our welcome party. We will serve drinks and dinner. Feb 21st is the day of the pro am. 9am shotgun start and lunch/awards after. You are able to depart that evening or you are welcome to stay a second night and go back out to play more golf. We will have some fun golf activities that afternoon, too! Feb 22nd will be the BackSwing Invitational day. Tee times start at 8am. This is for ALL our professional lady pros only. You are welcome to stay and cheer them on or you are able to depart that morning, too! 

We want you to bring your fave group, eat, drink, golf and enjoy the experience. This is about YOU and your support to BackSwing. Hope to see you there!!

McKenzie@BackSwingGolfEvents.com

480-535-5027

Great reminder! It’s too easy to get caught up in the distractions that are not within your control. Focus on what you can control and remind yourself why you are doing it!

Often when things get really hard, you are right there. 

This is the time to push more.

Growth comes in all forms.

At all stages of life. 

It's important to recognize and celebrate all of them.

As humans, we are predisposed to want to do more. 

When we think about growth in a professional sense, we often think about promotions, salary increases, and acquiring new skills. 

While these are all important aspects of career growth, they're not the only ones. 

Growth can also mean taking on new challenges, learning from failures, and developing stronger relationships with colleagues.

Similarly, growth in our personal lives can come in many different forms. 

It can mean developing new hobbies or interests, improving physical and mental health, or strengthening relationships with loved ones.

The key to achieving growth in all forms is to remain open-minded and curious. 

Be willing to try new things, take risks, and learn from our good and bad experiences. 

The most important factor-- 

Surround ourselves with people who support our growth and inspire us to be our best selves.

Growth isn't just about reaching the top - it's about the journey to get there.

Enjoy the ride! 🎢

#growth #career #people

It takes outstanding leadership to build a great team, and great companies operate best and with the most longevity when employees work with a team mentality. The ability to master the “art of people” and knowing how to maneuver hundreds (if not thousands) of people at the right place and at the right time is one of the highest pinnacles of leadership success.

Each team member brings something unique to the table, so it’s essential to treat each role as a critical arm of your business. Each team member should feel like their job matters without ever asking themselves, “Why am I even here?”

All great leaders know exactly how to activate the talent that surrounds them. Leaders must know their team and understand how they are wired because this will allow everyone to commit to attaining the organization’s purpose and vision, but more importantly, to help each person become the very best version of themselves.

Many leaders and managers think that putting the organization's mission statement on a wall is enough for employees to feel this connection. It is not. 

The eighth element of employee engagement is a strictly emotional need and a higher-level one at that. Employees cannot energize themselves to reach their full potential without knowing how their job fits into the grander scheme of things. https://lnkd.in/gRaXa4Bi

"You tend to the soul through the body." - Anne Lamott on the Good Life Project®podcast.

When work is a challenge and we feel disengaged, is it possible that re-engaging requires a returning to our practical needs?

- The water breaks and resulting bathroom breaks,
- the annoyingly persistent need to eat,
- the venture from the desk to connect with another human,
- the walk outside to feel sunshine and breathe fresh air,
- the awkward stretching or "feet up the wall" that gets blood flowing to the brain.

Maybe the nurturing of our bodies also nurtures our souls and in turn nurtures our work. Maybe the antidote to disengagement requires re-engagement to the whole of our selves.

And when our work does not allow that, or directly inhibits it, maybe we should consider if it's worth the life it's taking from us.

Just maybe.

It’s the season of giving—what better way to check year-end giving off your list than by donating to one of the wonderful nonprofit organizations that I work with at GolfStatus!

Outlook Enrichment is a private nonprofit rehabilitation agency for the blind and visually impaired. They provide a wide range of services to meet their community's unique needs of individuals living with vision loss.

Their sister company, Outlook Nebraska, employs more than 60 visually impaired individuals at its Omaha production facility, making it the largest employer of the blind in the region. Their employment opportunities for those with vision loss range from customer service and marketing to accounting, human resources, training, information technology, and manufacturing. Their experience shows that almost any work environment can be adapted to accommodate employees with visual impairment.

Earlier this year, I was invited out to help out with their annual golf event, Tee It Up Fore Sight, which is paired with their Stanley M. Truhlsen, Jr. Blind Golfer Clinic for the visually impaired who are interested in golf. Their on-course challenges during the round definitely gave their participants a very special perspective on the game of golf and visual impairment. 

Did I convince you to donate yet? If so, click here to donate to their cause! https://lnkd.in/gsvaFRwp

🚨 I am officially DEBT FREE!  🙌🏻 

Over the past 26 months, I worked tirelessly with the end goal in mind to eliminate my student loan debt as quickly as possible. I learned how to say "no", found a way to live on significantly less than I earned each month, and continued to battle through even when the end goal seemed miles away.

I refused to let the burden of debt weigh me down one day longer than necessary, and I certainly wasn't going to sit back until my loans were "forgiven" at the cost of a future generation. Hard work, grit, and determination helped me celebrate the best 4th of July weekend yet 🇺🇸

A huge thank you to Dave Ramsey for the #debtsnowball plan and life-changing books/podcasts, my family, and all of the friends who pushed me on this journey. 🎉🏆

DEBT. FREE. 🥂

TL;DR - exposing our young people to new/more opportunities is the key to growth as a community and state


My wife, Jenny Cuddy, has been so supportive of my vision and career changes that led to launching MOVE Venture Capital & Nebraska Startup Academy at the start of the year and I couldn't have done it without her as I've run around the state the past few months... 

With her starting back at the Omaha Public Schools this week it allowed me the opportunity to take my kids to an entrepreneurial event last night Millwork Commons. The first time they've seen my job... 

Don't get me wrong, it was not their first choice for how to spend the evening and they let me know more than once, but their questions really took me to first-principle thinking and our conversation afterward was great (plus we got ice cream!). 

Questions we discussed on the way home: 
- "The girls that were talking... they are the boss?" 
"They made their companies? So I could start my own company?"
 Thank you Jessica Korinek & Jennifer Lea for being representation! (and to Jina, Sally, Marina, Natasha among others in the room!)

- "Who told them they could start a company?"

- "So, are they rich since they own it?"

- "Do you learn how to be a founder in school?" 

- And probably most importantly... "Do all your meetings have cookies and grilled cheese?"

In all seriousness, it was a lot of fun to share the experience with them and yes "founder" was added to their ever-growing list of "what do you want to be when you grow up" alongside teacher, soccer player, superhero, YouTuber, doctor, musician, and artist... 

I love entrepreneurship, the ability to create something from nothing but, more importantly, I love opportunity... Opportunity to grow, connect, fail, and learn, and last night reinforced in my mind the need for exposure of opportunity for all our young people. 

I often remind myself I don't know what I don't know, and believe if we can help make the "unknown unknown" - known for more young people and have more of these first-principle conversations about what opportunities are available for you "to grow up and be" I believe the possibilities for growth here are limitless. 

I'm very excited about the future when we are working together.

Last week our company added “loss of pregnancy” to our bereavement leave definition.

It may be a small change, but it’s a really big deal.

Like mental health challenges, miscarriages have been secreted away and treated as a private and shameful pain for far too long.

Too many of us have struggled silently through the physical and emotional effects of a pregnancy loss. 

We’ve had to walk in the office door and act “professional” while feeling utterly empty and broken inside.

Now we’re finally recognizing this for what it is, and giving employees space and time to heal.

It means so much to be acknowledged and cared for in this way. 

 #employeewellbeing  #proudmoment #peoplefirst

I’m going to give you a piece of advice that could literally change your entire business in 2019: 

Create content that’s contextual to 50-100 different demographics, and run those content pieces as ads on Facebook and Instagram. 

The reason most people fail with Facebook ads is that they go “wide.” They create one ad, and they target broad. 

(Many do this because it reduces "cost per lead", but they don't realize that it makes their ad less effective in terms of driving actual business results). 

In the modern world... we have the incredible ability of being able to create content specific for different demographics. 

You can create a video for a 60 year old man that’s interested in the military, or a 21 year old African American woman. 

The reality is, the feed is only getting noisier and noisier. If your ad isn’t contextual, it’s not getting consumed. 

Period. 

I talk about it more in this video, check it out and let me know what you thought!
